titlestmt.titleproper: Coronet Magazine Military History Project Records
titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of the collection at Syracuse University

list.item: Mar 2016 - rehoused, flattened, inventory expanded substantially (MS)

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.unittitle: Coronet Magazine Military History Project Records
did.abstract: Correspondence and memorabilia to, from, and about soldiers (Civil War through Korea)
did.langmaterial: Majority in English, one book in German

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Coronet Magazine was published from October 13, 1936 to March 1971 and ran for 299 issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The Coronet Magazine Military History Project Records consists of correspondence and World War II material.

Correspondence consists of letters, postcards and other correspondence sent home by American soldiers in five wars -- Civil War, World War I, World War II, Vietnam, and Korea. There is also a Civil War diary for the year 1892 and extensive collections of letters from a World War I private and a World War II officer, as well as a small amount of memorabilia.
World War II in Europe items include a Nazi flag, a Nazi history book, aerial photographs, maps and newspapres/news clippings (e.g., 8 Dec 1942 with headline "JAPAN STARTS WAR.").
A small number of military pamphlets relating to Nuclear war complete the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged chronologically by war. World War II in Europe material is arranged alphabetically by type of material.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.
Access to audiorecordings requires advance notice to produce a use copy.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Coronet Magazine Military History Project Records,
&su_name;

did.abstract: buttons from uniform of Grand Army of the Republic
Garton S. Churchill, Floyd B. Bremerman, Russell Mustard, Leonard Pratt, Robert Bloomingdale and others; includes photographs and postcards
letters to his father in Illinois; includes photographs
New York City attorney who wrote a serialized letter to soldiers on his mailing list, arranged as "volumes" bu him; contains both letters he wrote and letters sent to him by others
New York City attorney who wrote a serialized letter to soldiers on his mailing list, arranged as "volumes" bu him; contains both letters he wrote and letters sent to him by others

letter from Casey, possibly transcribed by his mother Helen Long Casey as it is on her stationery, with notes at the end that talk about her son's death; also two letters from Casey's commanding officers
Air Force major and surgeon; letters to and from former patients and friends in the military
letters to Betsy Cran of Chicago and from Tony Puglio
bound volume of letters from Lt. Kempner, self-published by his parents after his death as "Letters from Sandy" (Stinehour Press, Lunenberg, VT)
one sheet with cartoons and humorous captions regarding the adventures of the 29th Infantry in Europe
large military-issue maps of areas in France and Germany, some with handwritten annotations and markings, including one hand-annotated as "Omaha Beach"
includes large oversize foldout map; various other items laid in

did.unittitle: Photobook, Deutschland Erwacht (Germany Awakens), Cigaretten Bildendienst, Altona-Bahrenfeld
did.abstract: Third Reich propaganda book containing dozens of printed and tipped-in photos as well as a very large (4') foldout photo of a rally in Nuremberg; an early publishing effort by the Nazi Party shortly after Adolf Hitler was appointed Chancellor
